put out.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to make a fire etc stop burning
put out.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The rescue services are still trying to put out the fires.
put out.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to make a light stop working by pressing or turning a button or switch
put out.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to put things where people can find and use them
put out.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: The girls helped her to put out the cups and plates.
put out.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: We were a little put out at not being invited to the wedding.
put out.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to make extra work or cause problems for someone
put out.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: Mary can’t come to dinner tonight. She hopes it won’t put you out.
put out.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to make an effort to do something that will help someone
put out.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: They had put themselves out to entertain her during her visit.
put out.translation[0].definitions[6].de: to take something outside your house and leave it there
put out.translation[0].definitions[6].no: put the washing out (=put clothes outside to dry)
put out.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: Remember to put the cat out before you go to bed.
put out.translation[0].definitions[7].de: to push your tongue out of your mouth, especially as a rude sign to someone
put out.translation[0].definitions[8].de: to move your hand etc forward and away from your body
put out.translation[0].definitions[8].ex: He put out his hand toward her.
put out.translation[0].definitions[9].de: to make someone unconscious before a medical operation
put out.translation[0].definitions[11].d: to broadcast or produce something for people to read or listen to
put out.translation[0].definitions[11].e: They put out a half-hour programme on young refugees.
put out.translation[0].definitions[12].d: to try to discover information or opinions by listening to people or watching what is happening
put out.translation[0].definitions[12].e: He had already put out feelers with local employers but they hadn’t been interested.
put out.translation[0].definitions[13].d: if a ship puts out, it starts to sail
put out.translation[0].definitions[14].d: if a woman puts out, she has sex with a man
put out.translation[0].definitions[15].d: to prevent a baseball player from running around the bases, for example by catching the ball that they have hit
put out.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: She felt put out that she hadn’t been consulted.
put out.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: A great many people are involved in putting out a newspaper.
put out.translation[2].definitions[1].de: if a company puts out a piece of work, it sends the work to be done by someone who does not work for the company
put out.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: These days we put out a lot of work to freelancers.
